docs.lead_paragraph: Gastric bypass operations may be an appropriate treatment for obesity in teenagers, but only for those who are severely overweight and ready to make a lifelong commitment to dietary changes, according to a study being released today in the journal Pediatrics. Dr. Thomas H. Inge of the University of Cincinnati, the study's lead author, said that he had seen reports of several hundred cases in which gastric bypass had been performed on adolescents but that he believed the procedure was becoming far more common than that.

headline.main: Bypass Is Called a Last Resort

docs.abstract: Dr Thomas H Inge, University of Cincinnati researcher, leads study on use of gastric bypass operations to treat obesity in young people; study, published in journal Pediatrics, suggests risks and benefits of surgery are same for young people and adults, but suggests that surgery be restricted to those over age 13 with severe obesity; also recommends that surgery be delayed until patient is 95 percent of their predicted adult height; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mention anorexia or bulimia, and what comes to mind is a skin-and-bones teenager caught in a ferocious struggle to be thin. But doctors say they are seeing a disturbing trend: a growing group of women in their 30's, 40's and 50's who have eating disorders. Most have husbands, children, jobs and aging parents. They live with their secret while trying to manage the other aspects of their lives.

headline.main: Older Women, Too, Struggle With a Dangerous Secret

docs.abstract: Doctors see rise in women in 30's, 40's and 50's who suffer from eating disorders like bulimia and anorexia; Dr Margo Maine, eating disorder expert and author of book The Shape We're In: Overcoming Women's Obsessions with Weight, Food and Body Image, holds that older women are hesitant to seek help because they think illness is something they should have grown out of and is exclusively teenager's problem; dealing with loss can be powerful trigger of eating disorder in older women; doctors stress that onset of disorder rarely appears later in life with patient generally managing illness over time; complications and treatment of anorexia and bulimia described; photos (M)
